c74object.name: fl.register~
c74object.description: The left input triggers recall, whilst the right input stores a frame. The mode parameter is used to set whether the right input causes output.

entry.name: /mode [instantiation enum]
entry.description:
Sets the behaviour of the right input:
store - stores without output.
pass - stores and outputs.
[0] - store [1] - pass

objarg.name: default-input
objarg.digest: The input vector to use for any disconnected inputs
objarg.description: Values typed as arguments will be used as a vector for any inputs that are not connected. Either single values or multi-valued vectors can be entered. The behaviour is similar to that for arguments to standard objects such as +~, *~ or zl.reg.

method.name: info
method.description:
Print info about fl.register~ to the max window for reference purposes. If no arguments are provided then all information is posted to the Max window. Else, a set of flags is used to select which sections of the reference to display, and whether or not the information should be provided in a shortened form.
The following flags are available:
description - display the object description.inputs - display info on inputs.outputs - display info on outputs.io - display info on both inputs and outputs.parameters - display info on the object parameters.quick - display shorten versions of any info displayed.

method.name: frame
method.description: Used internally by FrameLib's connection routines. User messages have no effect.

method.name: sync
method.description: Used internally by FrameLib's connection routines. User messages have no effect.

attribute.name: rt
attribute.description:
Sets the realtime state for fl.register~. When set to 0 fl.register~ can form part of a non-realtime network for processing in message threads, using buffer~ objects for audio IO.
More info on non-realtime processing with FrameLib can be found in Tutorial 11.

attribute.name: id
attribute.description:
Sets the context name for fl.register~.
More info on FrameLib contexts can be found in Tutorial 10.
